sections.text: Use must have when you're certain something happened. Use can't have when you're certain something didn't happen. Both are based on evidence or logical deduction.

sections.structure: must have + past participle / can't have + past participle
examples: I'm certain he left ‚Üí He must have left
It's impossible she saw me ‚Üí She can't have seen me

examples.original: The lights are off and the door is locked. I'm certain everyone left the building.
Her coat is still here. I'm sure she hasn't gone home yet.
The grass is soaking wet. Obviously it rained during the night.
He doesn't speak French. There's no way he understood what they said.
She's crying. Clearly someone told her the bad news.
The shop was closed. It's impossible they bought anything there.
He knows all the details. Obviously someone informed him about the meeting.
She was in Madrid. There's no way she saw me in Barcelona.
The car won't start. Clearly I left the lights on all night.
He arrived before me. It's impossible he took my parking space.

sections.text: Use may have, might have, or could have to express possibility about the past when you're not certain. They all suggest something was possible but you don't know for sure.
may have ‚âà 50% probability, might have ‚âà 40-50% probability, could have = general possibility

examples.original: Perhaps she missed her train this morning.
Maybe they forgot about our meeting.
It's possible someone took my umbrella by mistake.
Perhaps he didn't receive my email.
Maybe she changed her mind about coming.
It's possible the letter got lost in the post.
Perhaps they went home early because of the rain.
examples.after: home early because of the rain.

examples.original: Maybe I made a mistake with the calculations.
It's possible he heard the news from someone else.
Perhaps the bus broke down on the way here.

sections.text: Use should have or ought to have to criticize past actions or express regret. It means something was the right thing to do, but it didn't happen. Use shouldn't have for criticism of wrong actions.
Expressing regret about your own actions, criticizing others' behavior, or giving advice about what was the right thing to do in the past.

examples.original: I didn't study for the exam. I regret that now.
You didn't tell me about the problem. That was wrong.
We booked our holiday too late. Now everything's fully booked.
She trusted him with her money. That was a mistake.
He didn't listen to our advice. Now he's in trouble.
They didn't save any money. Now they can't afford the repairs.
I ate all the cake. Now I feel sick.
You didn't check the weather forecast. Now we're stuck in the rain.
She quit her job without having another one. That was foolish.
examples.after: her job without having another one.

examples.original: We didn't complain about the service. We regret that now.

sections.text: Use would have for imaginary or hypothetical results in the past. It shows what would have happened if the situation had been different.

sections.structure: If + past perfect, would have + past participle
examples: If I had known, I would have helped
If she had studied, she would have passed

examples.original: I didn't know about the problem, so I didn't help you.
examples.before: If I had known about the problem, I

examples.original: She wasn't invited to the party, so she didn't come.
examples.before: If she had been invited to the party, she

examples.original: We didn't have enough time, so we didn't visit the museum.
examples.before: If we had had enough time, we

examples.original: It rained all day, so we didn't go to the beach.
examples.before: If it hadn't rained all day, we

examples.original: He didn't see the warning sign, so he didn't stop.
examples.before: If he had seen the warning sign, he

examples.original: They studied hard, so they passed the exam.
examples.before: If they hadn't studied hard, they

examples.original: I was busy, so I couldn't attend the meeting.
examples.before: If I hadn't been busy, I

examples.original: She forgot to set her alarm, so she missed the train.
examples.before: If she hadn't forgotten to set her alarm, she

examples.original: We left early, so we avoided the traffic.
examples.before: If we hadn't left early, we

examples.original: He listened to the advice, so he succeeded.
examples.before: If he hadn't listened to the advice, he

sections.text: Use could have to talk about ability or opportunity that existed in the past but wasn't used. You had the chance or ability to do something, but you didn't do it.
Could have for possibility = 'maybe it happened'. Could have for ability = 'I was able to, but I didn't do it'.

examples.original: I was able to go to the party last night, but I decided to stay home.
examples.after: to the party, but I decided to stay home.

examples.original: She had the opportunity to study at Oxford, but she chose Cambridge instead.
examples.after: at Oxford, but she chose Cambridge.

examples.original: We were capable of finishing the project early, but we didn't work hard enough.
examples.after: the project early, but we didn't work hard enough.

examples.original: He had the chance to buy the house, but he hesitated too long.
examples.after: the house, but he hesitated too long.

examples.original: I was free to help you yesterday, but you didn't ask me.
examples.after: you yesterday, but you didn't ask me.

examples.original: They had the skills to win the competition, but they made too many mistakes.
examples.after: the competition, but they made too many mistakes.

examples.original: You were able to get better grades with more effort.
She had time to learn French before the trip, but she was too busy.
examples.after: French before the trip, but she was too busy.

examples.original: We had the option to invest in the company, but we didn't have enough information.
examples.after: in the company, but we didn't have enough information.

examples.original: He was capable of becoming a professional musician, but he chose a different career.
examples.after: a professional musician, but he chose a different career.

sections.text: Use will have + past participle to talk about actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future. Often used with 'by', 'before', or 'by the time'.
Common with: by next week, by 2026, by the time..., before summer, by then

examples.original: They will finish the building work before the end of the month.
examples.after: the building work by the end of the month.

examples.original: I will complete my degree before 2027.
She will read all the books before the exam starts.
examples.after: all the books before the exam starts.

examples.original: We will save enough money before summer arrives.
The builders will construct the house before Christmas.
I will finish cooking when you arrive home.
examples.after: cooking by the time you arrive home.

examples.original: They will leave when we get there.
examples.after: by the time we get there.

examples.original: She will graduate when her parents visit next year.
examples.after: by the time her parents visit.

examples.original: I will live in this city for ten years next month.
examples.after: in this city for ten years next month.

examples.original: They will work on this project for six months by April.
examples.after: on this project for six months by April.
